message: ouch!

what's the mechanism called?
thanks, peter!

a large portion of it also has to do with the way academics are evaluated and what success means (# of publications), where disseminating anything other than the publication is seen as having minimal (or even negative) utility for the researcher
I didn't say it yesterday, but I do say it often.
it's really hard to get neurophysiologist to share their data because it is both very rich and very hard to obtain, so each lab just hoards it in their own data silos
agreed.
ok, thanks - I think I clicked the button twice :)
<- Takes advice from Bruce Schneier.
She's basically saying that people should keep in mind that scientists are stubborn, and plan for that?
Or maybe Google+ now.
@ivanov http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antikythera_mechanism
Maybe I'm being naive, but many of the legal and practical barriers in scientific dissemination seem to be exclusively the fault of for-profit scientific publishing outliving its usefulness...
w00t Girl Talk!
@RobertKern Did you see the feedback that folks had for G+ devs, where the most requested feature was "public groups"?
G+ and FB are walled gardens?
... </sarcasm>?
Hah! Pool your resources! Sounds like the neurophysiologists could take a lesson from the physicists.
there's no preassure for them to (neither from public, nor funding agencies)
I don't think so.
Pretty sure it's quite uncontroversial. Except for people who reject the fossil record as a source of knowledge altogether.
But, yes -- the role of journals *should* be to keep researchers honest, *force* the publication of data, maybe even archive it for them.

Re: patents, I recall hearing someone say yesterday that the best strategy for software developers is arguably to just not read patents, since if you know for certain that you're violating one you can be found doubly or triply liable.
Was that someone Robert Kern?  He makes a  point of making it well known that he does not read patents...
Holy crap, she literally cranked up her cadence in a very uniform manner
That's impressive.  Oh, it slowed down again.
Isn't the Cambrian Explosion just a theory, not a fact??

Or Mendeley

@pwang stubborn AND lazy
The key thing about Facebook is that you now have an entire generation of grad students already on one platform.
can we get sarcasm tags in here? all three of those are walled gardens, science has no place in them any more than it does behind a pay wall for anyone in the public
the insides of facebook are not accessible without an account
